name: 7th Dragon
description:
The world is populated by dragons - beings of pure id, harvesting its life for their own sake. Standing in opposition to them are hunters, humans who set out in groups to explore the world. The player controls a characters who founds a new guild with the goal of playing as a hunter. At the start of the game, the player's guild takes on small-time jobs, but ends up being pulled into a world-shaping story.

This turn-based RPG has no predefined characters; the player creates all of the characters they use, including their main character. Each character can be defined as one of seven classes, each of which has four unique appearances; after creation, characters can be further customized by learning abilities from skill trees in order to customize their role in battle. A player's guild can have up to sixteen characters total, up to four of whom can be selected at a time to form a party. The core of the game is structured around quests, which are available from quest boards in each town; these can range from simple fetch quests to complex quests involving dungeon crawling and travelling the world.

shot.caption: Our first view of a human town in the introduction.
The first thing we do in the game is create a character by picking their class and appearance.
Each class has four different appearances available; there's no gameplay difference, but it lets the player choose whatever sprite and portrait they like.
The grid at the bottom of the screen shows the player's current guild. This is empty at the start of the game, but it can be built up with up to sixteen characters.
Adding the starting character to the guild!
Meeting with the guild registration master. She allows the player to register new characters, adjust the guild membership, and set up parties.
These beautiful splash screens are displayed the first time the player reaches a town.
Visiting the quest office - this is where the player can take on available quests, or report in when they're completed.
The "custom" menu allows players to spend skill points on customizing their characters.
Building a party; each character can be assigned a position in front or back.
Battle; choosing a character's actions from a wheel.
There are cute cut-in animations when characters attack or use abilities.
